review.title: Long-term Causal Effects via Behavioral Game Theory
review.abstract: Estimation of causal effects of interventions in dynamical systems of interacting agents is under-developed. In this paper, we explore the intricacies of this problem through standard approaches, and demonstrate the need for more appropriate methods. Working under the Neyman-Rubin causal model, we proceed to develop a causal inference method and we explicate the stability assumptions that are necessary for valid causal inference. Our method consists of a behavioral component that models the evolution of agent behaviors over time and informs on the long-term distribution of agent behaviors in the system, and a game-theoretic component that models the observed distribution of agent actions conditional on adopted behaviors. This allows the imputation of long-term estimates of quantities of interest, and thus the estimation of long-term causal effects of interventions. We demonstrate our method on a dataset from behavioral game theory, and discuss open problems to stimulate future research.
histories: 30th Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NIPS'16)
30th Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NIPS'16)

metadata.title: Statistical inference of long-term causal effects in multiagent systems under the Neyman-Rubin model

sections.text: In this paper, we examine the intricacies of this problem using standard approaches and highlight the need for more appropriate methodologies. In the Neyman-Rubin causal model, we develop a causal inference method and explain the stability assumptions required for a valid causal conclusion. Our method consists of a temporal component that models the evolution of behaviors that agents adopt over time, and a behavioral component that models the distribution of agent actions that depend on behaviors that are applied, enabling long-term estimates of interest parameters to be added and thus the estimation of long-term causal effects of interventions. We demonstrate our method using a data set from behavioral game theory and discuss open problems to stimulate future research.

However, Rapoport and Boebel (1992) considered two versions of the same game with (W, L) = ($10, − $6) and (W, L) = ($15, − $1). If player A selects action A1 and agent B selects action B3 in the first version, then agent A must pay $6 to agent B.2. Twenty subjects were randomized for each game, and each player played both as A and as B in a match-up with two different players. Each match-up lasted 2 sessions (periods) of 60 rounds, with each round consisting of a choice of strategy from each agent and a (possible) payout. The aggregate data for this experiment is shown in reports we have adopted within this game feature.

sections.heading: 3 Causal inference in multiagent systems: Estimand and sta-
sections.text: In this section, we formally define our estimate of interest and explain the stability assumptions required for valid causal conclusions based on the Neyman-Rubin model. First, we present our notation for the rest of this work. Consider an assignment mechanism that first takes into account a vector Z (0, 1) n of n elements, with Zi = 1 indicating that agent i has been assigned to the game G1 and Zi = 0 indicating that agent i has been assigned to the game G0; therefore, Z is the initial assignment of agents to games that remain the same during the experiment. We assume that the games progress in discrete increments.

sections.heading: 3.1 Stability assumptions for valid causal inference
sections.text: In the typical causal inference methods, extrapolation from one treatment assignment Z to another assignment Z = ββj behavior is achieved by various assumptions of stability. For example, the SUTVA assumption (Rubin, 1974) puts Yit (Z) = βββββi (Zi) i.e., the potential result for unit i depends only on the treatment assignment of the unit itself. The great virtue of this assumption is that an observed result Yit (Z) immediately informs us of potential outcomes {Yit (Z): Z ′ i = Zi}; i.e., for a variety of treatment assignments that could be realized, allowing us to more accurately assess the desired treatment effects. In our problem, strategic interference and dynamic behavior cannot justify such an assumption. Therefore, we need stability assumptions that are defined on populations of agents. For this reason, we expand our parameter space by introducing a number of behavioral behaviors.

sections.heading: 4 Concrete Methodology
sections.text: Building on the findings of Section 3, we are now developing a concrete methodology for estimating long-term causal effects defined in Equation (1). In Section 5, we are applying our method in the Rapoport and Boebel datasets (1992). However, for our behavioral model, we are adopting the quantum response (QLk) originally proposed by Stahl and Wilson (1994), and it has been shown that we can well predict observed human behavior in real-world behavioral experiments (Wright and Leyton-Brown, 2010). In QLk, agents possess an increasing degree of complexity. Following this earlier work, we will adopt k = 3 and thus consider a behavioral space with three different types of behavior: B = b0, b2}. Let's leave out the distribution theory of actions that an agent will perform after accepting behavior. In QLk, the distributions depend on an assumption of the quantum response that follows.

sections.heading: 5 Application
sections.text: Returning to the Rapoport and Boebel dataset (1992) presented in Table 2, we assume that diffuse priors exist for the parameters of the Quantum Best Response Model, in particular we consider π (λi) х Expo, i.e. an exponential random variable with a rate of about 1 / 10 for the parameters of the Quantum Best Response Model, a diffuse beta for the parameters of the Quantum Best Response Model, and a flat variance before the parameters of the current model. This is efficient because we know beforehand that the values of our parameters are limited; since exact conditionals are difficult to obtain under this model, we apply a Metropolis Hastings scheme with a suggestion distribution that only slightly disturbs the current model parameters.

sections.heading: 5.1 Estimation of long-term causal effects
sections.text: Using the MCMC strategy outlined above, we are able to obtain imputations of the causal effect (1) from the posterior predictive distribution of the model parameters. Figure 3 shows 1,000 posterior samples. The actual estimate, considered at t = 4, is equal to $0.054. Our estimates are able to capture the latent dynamic trend in the behavior of the agents. It should also be remembered that the predictions presented in Section 2.1 estimated a strongly significant negative effect of the introduction of Game Design G1 compared to G0 because they were misdirected by strong short-term effects in the opposite direction. Indeed, our estimates are distorted; the posterior summary of the long-term effect is 0.088 ± 0.021, representing approximately 63% of the actual value. However, this is quite reasonable in our application for the following reasons. Firstly, the date is limited to 3 periods that we significantly indicate this linear function will trigger the second divisability of the decision; secondly, it is necessary for the prediction of the second phase.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion
sections.text: In this paper, we have examined the problem of estimating the long-term causal impact of interventions in multilateral systems within the framework of the Neyman-Rubin causal model. Two characteristics make this problem conceptually and technically challenging. First, strategic interference between competing actors leads to the exposure of a set of sufficient stability assumptions within the Neyman-Rubin model, i.e. that some kind of equilibrium is achieved.

referenceMentions.context: Fisher, evaluation of intervention effects hinges on an unambiguous interpretation of all possible experiment outcomes, and so “it is always needful to forecast all possible results of the experiment” (Fisher, 1935).

Current methods assume away such a possibility through a stable unit-treatment value assumption (Rubin, 1974) or assume that interference arises from a static network of units and employ network randomization designs, such as cluster randomization (Ugander et al.

Current methods assume away such a possibility through a stable unit-treatment value assumption (Rubin, 1974) or assume that interference arises from a static network of units and employ network randomization designs, such as cluster randomization (Ugander et al., 2013) or sequential randomization (Toulis and Kao, 2013).

For example, Athey et al. (2011) developed a method to compare two formats of U.

For example, Athey et al. (2011) developed a method to compare two formats of U.S. timber auctions. Their approach is to use data from one auction in order to estimate aggregate bidder value distributions that act as primitives in a structural model, and thus use those estimates to predict the equilibrium outcomes on the other auction. Although not causal, their estimates do capture the notion of longterm intervention effects. However, as we explain in more detail in Section 2.1, they assume away considerations of temporal behavior. Our goal in this work is to estimate long-term causal effects of interventions that are valid under the Neyman-Rubin model in the setting of economic mechanisms with interacting agents. In Section 2, we introduce a concrete problem instance using data from a real-world behavioral experiment by Rapoport and Boebel (1992). We further provide an overview of related approaches to the problem and demonstrate the need for a valid causal inference method.

For example, Athey et al. (2011) developed a method to compare two formats of U.S. timber auctions. Their approach is to use data from one auction in order to estimate aggregate bidder value distributions that act as primitives in a structural model, and thus use those estimates to predict the equilibrium outcomes on the other auction. Although not causal, their estimates do capture the notion of longterm intervention effects. However, as we explain in more detail in Section 2.1, they assume away considerations of temporal behavior. Our goal in this work is to estimate long-term causal effects of interventions that are valid under the Neyman-Rubin model in the setting of economic mechanisms with interacting agents. In Section 2, we introduce a concrete problem instance using data from a real-world behavioral experiment by Rapoport and Boebel (1992). We further provide an overview of related approaches to the problem and demonstrate the need for a valid causal inference method. In Section 3, we begin by introducing two novel components in the Neyman-Rubin model. The first component is a behavioral state-space where each state is a distribution of a finite number of behaviors over the agent population in the mechanism; this behavioral state is allowed to vary temporally, but it is considered to be latent. Although the treatment assignment mechanism is allowed to affect the initial behavioral state, the features of the aforementioned temporal evolution are intrinsic to the mechanism and thus the evolution is stable under the treatment assignment. The second component is the game-theoretic model which defines the distribution of agent actions, given the payoff structure of the mechanism and the underlying behavioral state, and thus is also stable under the treatment assignment. Taken together, the two aforementioned stability assumptions equip the Neyman-Rubin model for definition and estimation of valid long-term causal effects. In Sections 4 and 5, we develop and demonstrate our method by analyzing the dataset by Rapoport and Boebel (1992). In particular, we adopt an instance of the quantal k-level (QLk) behavioral model introduced by Stahl and Wilson (1994).

Although not causal, their estimates do capture the notion of longterm intervention effects. However, as we explain in more detail in Section 2.1, they assume away considerations of temporal behavior. Our goal in this work is to estimate long-term causal effects of interventions that are valid under the Neyman-Rubin model in the setting of economic mechanisms with interacting agents. In Section 2, we introduce a concrete problem instance using data from a real-world behavioral experiment by Rapoport and Boebel (1992). We further provide an overview of related approaches to the problem and demonstrate the need for a valid causal inference method. In Section 3, we begin by introducing two novel components in the Neyman-Rubin model. The first component is a behavioral state-space where each state is a distribution of a finite number of behaviors over the agent population in the mechanism; this behavioral state is allowed to vary temporally, but it is considered to be latent. Although the treatment assignment mechanism is allowed to affect the initial behavioral state, the features of the aforementioned temporal evolution are intrinsic to the mechanism and thus the evolution is stable under the treatment assignment. The second component is the game-theoretic model which defines the distribution of agent actions, given the payoff structure of the mechanism and the underlying behavioral state, and thus is also stable under the treatment assignment. Taken together, the two aforementioned stability assumptions equip the Neyman-Rubin model for definition and estimation of valid long-term causal effects. In Sections 4 and 5, we develop and demonstrate our method by analyzing the dataset by Rapoport and Boebel (1992). In particular, we adopt an instance of the quantal k-level (QLk) behavioral model introduced by Stahl and Wilson (1994). The latent behavioral state is thus defined as a distribution on k distinct behavior types, and the game-theoretic model is defined through the quantal responses of the associated behaviors.

Working on a real-world dataset from a behavioral experiment (Rapoport and Boebel, 1992), we showed how our method can be applied for estimation of a long-term effect of intervention in the payoff structure of a game design in normal-form.

metadata.abstractText: Estimation of causal effects of interventions in dynamical systems of interacting agents is under-developed. In this paper, we explore the intricacies of this problem through standard approaches, and demonstrate the need for more appropriate methods. Working under the Neyman-Rubin causal model, we proceed to develop a causal inference method and we explicate the stability assumptions that are necessary for valid causal inference. Our method consists of a temporal component that models the evolution of behaviors that agents adopt over time, and a behavioral component that models the distribution of agent actions conditional on adopted behaviors. This allows the imputation of long-term estimates of quantities of interest, and thus the estimation of long-term causal effects of interventions. We demonstrate our method on a dataset from behavioral game theory, and discuss open problems to stimulate future research.
